name: 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol, 3-methyl-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3901
Reason: 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a methyl group linked in a linear fashion. The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point. The exact impact of the methyl group depends on its exact arrangement and the specific compound. For 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol, the methyl group can be estimated to add approximately +10°C due to increased molecular weight and rigidity.
